content: I'm going to add cover art if there are no objections.

Loved the idea, hated the statement. Kind of hard to determine what's going on... well, not hard, but a bit annoyingly time consuming.

Here's what's going on in test case 5 "This problem is beyond me": https://ibb.co/kXxh1z

Maybe this image could be added as an example?

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
Can the output be NOT MOVING due to a jam? For example 3 gears arranged in a triangle formation which cannot physically turn?
This could use a specified constraint that no two gears are in the same place. I'm using, you're using, anyone deserves to use it!

Do you agree with this improvement? "The gears do not overlap."

(Actually had to fix two test cases after checking this in my solution.)

Yes indeed. When a gear is forced both in CW and in CCW direction it actually cannot move.  
This case is covered by the test cases, I called it interlocking, but perhaps 'Jammed' is a clearer name for that test case. I will rename it.

Same issue. Although the working of gears is pretty intuitive, I think a few explanatory lines would be appreciated:

- two gears in contact rotate in opposite directions
- if two gears moving in same direction come into contact, the entire system can't move
- this is probably very redundant, but "two gears are in contact when the two circles defining the gears touch each other i.e. distance between centres = sum of radii"

Interlocking sounded better IMHO.
Jammed means they should turn, but can't because someone threw an non-gear external object (typically: a wrench, but messed up paper does the job too).

Overlapping is a bit much.

I'd say two gears with the same center would overlap, yet that's usually not a problem. I mean, it makes perfect senses for two gears to roll around the same axis, it happens a lot in actual mechanics.

It's a problem when they have the same radius, because then we'd have to take a decision on whether or not they touch, and (probably) decide that even though they touch they're not turning in opposite directions. That makes it an ugly exception.

So yes, eliminating overlap does fix it, but it could be a bit overkill ^^

I think no overlap is the cleanest, because it best fits a model of a physical system. If we would allow multiple gears on the same axis then we need to take height (and width) of the gears into account to determine if they mesh. Following the idea that it is just gears on a plane, it makes sense that they don't overlap.

It could be a good start for another puzzle though. :)

Well, I'm fine with that too.

My fright would have been that it made generating test cases harder, but if you're over that there's nothing to worry about. :D
